STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 2, 2021
Leticia Pittman
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
RE: License #: CB110403982
Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton Harbor
185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
Dear Ms. Pittman:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/25-
11/1/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB110403982
Licensee Name: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Address: Suite 3A
360 South Division
Grand Rapids, MI 49503
Licensee Telephone #: (616) 243-9122
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Alisa Otto, Designee
Name of Facility: Catholic Charities West Michigan - Benton
Harbor
Facility Address: 185 E. Main Street St.102
Benton Harbor, MI 49022
Facility Telephone #: (269) 593-1000

CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
Receipt of this information is documented by the presence of
the Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care Medical
Authorization card (DHS-3762) dated before or at the time of
placement.
1 of 6 open foster care files reviewed was missing a medical authorization card.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to
a youth before placement in independent living.
1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain documentation that the
applicable program statement was provided to the youth.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living
with a copy of the agency’s policies and procedures
required by this rule.
1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain documentation that the
applicable policies and procedures were provided to the youth.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be
reviewed and updated at least once every 90 calendar days
and a copy provided to the youth.
1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain documentation that a
contract was created or updated.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
4

signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
1 of 3 adoptive family files reviewed documented a deferral of recommendation at 90
days; however, the deferral was the result of the worker not requesting needed
documents in a timely manner.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
1 of 4 applicable staff files reviewed contained documentation that the training was
not completed timely.
FOM 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT, AND
P. 1 DISCHARGE
Life Skills Assessment - The Casey Life Skills Assessment
must be completed within 90 days of a youth turning 14,
and annually thereafter. For youth who are 14 or older when
they enter care, the assessment should be completed
within 90 days of entering care.
For youth who are placed in residential, it is the residential
case worker who ensures the Casey Life Skills Assessment
if completed.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable
living arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to
placement in independent living, the caseworker must
assess the youth, with the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as
being prepared for independent living and demonstrate a
pattern of mature decision making.
5

1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain documentation verifying the
completion of the required Casey Life Skills Assessment.
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
P. 5 & 12 & 16
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days
of the FTM.
2 of 8 total open case files reviewed (6FC & 2 IL) were missing required FTM’s
FOM 722-07F PERMANENCY PLANNING - PPFWR AND APPLA
P. 8 & 9
For PPFWR and APPLA, the following forms must be
completed as part of the permanency plan approval packet:
 DHS-569, Permanency Goal Support Agreement.
Provide a copy to each participant, upload a copy to the
Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS, and include the
original agreement in the permanency plan approval
packet.
 Permanency Pact.
6

Complete the Permanency Pact Certificate with the youth
and supportive adult(s)/relative caregiver.
Provide a copy to each participant, upload a copy to the
Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS, and include the
original agreement in the permanency plan approval
packet.
 DHS-347, Permanency Goal Approval.
The assigned caseworker must complete this form.
Upload a copy to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS
and attach the original as the cover sheet to the
permanency plan approval packet.
 Independent Living Plan, if applicable.
Note: If independent living will be the youth's living
arrangement, then a detailed independent living plan must
be submitted with the permanency goal approval packet;
see FOM 722-03C, Preparation and Placement of Older
Youth, for detailed information on independent living plans.
1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain the required documentation.
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must
review the case service plan and all linked assessments
and treatment plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case
service plan review may occur during monthly case
consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
3 of 8 total open case files reviewed (6FC & 2 IL) contained service plans not
approved within the required timeframe.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
7

Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review,
and I will have the opportunity to express my
disagreement with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan when the information is
presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign
the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and
document actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the treatment plan.
CI-17-099 All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate
case members within 30 days of the report date.
4 of 8 total open case files reviewed (6FC & 2 IL) contained service plans that did
not have all signatures attained as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-08C)
9/24/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
8

Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
4 of 8 total open case files reviewed (6FC & 2 IL) did not contain all required action
summaries.
FOM 722-16 YOUNG ADULT VOLUNTARY FOSTER CARE
P. 14
The DHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. A copy
must be uploaded into MiSACWIS a copy must be given to
the youth.
1 of 1 files of youth in YAVFC did not contain the required 1295 for every visit.
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
9

and obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
2 of 8 total open case files reviewed (6FC & 2 IL) did not contain all medical
passport with required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-08C)
9/24/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/8/2020
ADM 980 ADOPTION CLOSING SUMMARY (DHS-222)
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14
calendar days of the adoption finalization date to the foster
care worker and the Department of Health and Services
(DHHS) adoption monitor for purchase of service cases for
inclusion in the child’s permanent record. The DHS-222,
Adoption Closing Summary must be used for this purpose.
1 of 3 youth adoption files reviewed did not contain the required Adoption Closing
Summary.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 PATP signatures must be signed in the correct spot, have the applicable boxes
checked, and be accurately dated.
 Medical Passport must be maintained in the medical section of the case record.
 Supervisors must approve action summaries on or near the same date as the
worker in order to be considered “complete.”
 Make sure all aspects of "required discussion" required per FOM 722-06H P. 13
are documented during all monthly visits with the caregiver
 Reasonable efforts must be made to make an adoptive family recommendation
within the required timeframe.
 All documents must be uploaded in MiSACWIS. It is imperative that a complete
case record be maintained. Once a case is closed, it cannot be re-opened to add
missing documents.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
10

 All youth living independently (Placement Type is Independent Living) are
required to meet the DCWL IL rule requirements, regardless of legal status
(YAVFC, PW, TCW.)
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Renewal inspection 9/24/2020, CAP approved 10/8/2020. The agency is in
compliance with the aspects of that CAP not cited as repeat violations within this
report.
Chief Administrator Assessment: While the agency does not have a Chief
Administrator currently assigned, the agency’s previous chief administrator
completed the assessment prior to leaving the agency. She identified that staff
turnover, new staff resulting from agency growth, and restrictions related to the
COVID-19 pandemic resulted in some areas of non-compliance, which was
evidenced in the file review.
Staff Interviews: The agency staff reported no concerns with the support or training
they receive from their superiors. They do report staff turnover has been challenging,
but the current team works well together and help one another when needed.
VII. DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS
No safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
November 2, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
11

Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 2, 2021

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
